Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans le quartier à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 27 500 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sabali are composed of five married women who average 33 years of age and two children. They reside in the Ouayerma I district in the city of Sikasso and do commerce, such as in: shoes, firewood, damask fabrics, basins, and plastic buckets.

To satisfy their burgeoning customer base, the group members have joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago and are on their fifth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. They plan to use this loan to buy 4 dozen shoes, 10 loads of firewood, 30 children’s outfits, a dozen “pagnes” (colorful West African cloth) and damask fabrics (five meters, well-dyed), and 50 plastic tubs and buckets. Their supplies are gotten either in Cote d’Ivoire, which is a nation bordering Mali, or in Bamako (capital of Mali), or locally in Sikasso.

The goods are sold at the retail level and mostly for cash in the marketplaces of Sikasso (Médine marketplace and the grand marketplace of the city) and in the district, to customers composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 27,500 francs CFA per month that will be used to provide for the family and to invest the rest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Lux

texts.en: Lux S. is 22 years old and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She stays at home and raises pigs to earn approximately $1 every day, while her husband works as a fisherman. He catches and sells fish to the market-seller, earning around $4 per day. This couple has two young children. Mrs. Lux S. is asking for a loan to purchase fishing nets for her husband and increase her livestock by adding more pigs.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and raise pigs.

loans.name: Todjiniso

texts.en:
Todjiniso S.’s passion lies with children. A married mother of three, Todjiniso opened her business selling women’s clothing with the goal of providing a better standard of living for her family. For the past three years, Todjiniso has successfully operated her business at the market. With her profits, she not only has improved her children's living standards, she has been able to support her elderly parents as well.

Todjiniso has requested a loan of $675 to restock her clothing inventory. An optimistic businesswoman, Todjiniso plans to use the loan to continue developing her business and supporting her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase new women's clothing for the spring season to resell.

loans.name: Segerina

texts.en:
Segerina P. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to open up a bar at the market.

Segerina is 49 years old and is married with a husband that is a security guard. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a bar at the market

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Thuý Nguyễn (0) is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Hiải Dương. She is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Thuý owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Thuý has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2002, Thuý joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Thuý has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.

Thuý is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. Thuý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
Felicitas es socia del Banco Comunal Alianza
Felicitas es casada, tiene 50 años y 4 hijos, Felicitas viaja a la selva ayacuchana en donde vende verduras y ropa a pedido, a donde viaja los días lunes y regresa los días viernes, sus ventas los realiza en el mercado de la ciudad de San Francisco.
Felicitas necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa.
Los sueños de Felicitas son ayudar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales, mejorar su negocio y tener un negocio en la ciudad de Ayacucho.
texts.en:
Felicitas is a member of the Banco Comunal Alianza. She is married, 50 years old, and has four children. On Mondays she travels to the jungle around Ayacucho to sell vegetables and clothing in the city of San Francisco, and returns home on Fridays. Felicitas needs a loan of 1000 soles, which she will invest in purchasing clothing. Her dreams are to help her children become successful, to expand her business, and to establish a business in the city of Ayacucho.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Antonia Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Antonia del Carmen A. Sánchez, tiene la edad de 47 años, habita en el barrio Dennis Larios en la comunidad de Ticuantepe, junto a su esposo, el cual trabaja y le poya con los gastos del hogar, ellos tiene cuatro hijos, ya todos casados, los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida, ella desde hace ocho años trabaja en la agricultura, la mayor dificultad es la falta de financiamiento, ella inicio con sus propios esfuerzos. Con el financiamiento a comprar fertilizantes e insumos para aplicar al cultivo y mejorar su produccion
texts.en:
Mrs. Antonia del Carmen A. Sánchez is 47 years old and lives in the Dennis Larios neighborhood in the community of Ticuantepe with her husband, who works and helps with the household expenses. They have four children, all of whom are married. Her goal for her family is to improve their living conditions. She has been working in agriculture for eight years. Her main problem is a lack of financing; she started with her own effort. With the loan she will buy fertilizer and other materials to apply to her crops in order to increase her production.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and materials for her crops

loans.name: Mumtaz Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. 
Saima baji wants a loan to buy cycle repairing tools. 
Musarat baji wants a loan to buy plumbing supplies (taps and pipes) to sell. 
Ruqaiya baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. 

My name is Mumtaz and I have lived in a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. I operate a business sewing clothes, at my home, to help pay the utilities. My husband’s name is N. A.. He is a driver, by profession. He drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) and can’t get the whole money of his struggle. I am applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for my husband so that he gets the whole income of his efforts. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members; each member will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila es socia del Banco Comunal Suni que significa Abundante en quechua.
Lucila es casada, tiene 38 años y 2 hijos, Lucila se dedica a la preparación de comida, brinda sus servicios para diferentes agasajos de instituciones. Además Lucila tiene proyectado implementar una granja de cuy.
Lucila necesita un préstamo de 750 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de implementos para galpones.
Lucila sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Lucila is a member of the Village Bank called Suni, which means Abundant in Quechua. Luclia is married, is 38 years old and has two children. Lucila prepares food, providing her services for institutions’ various events. Additionally, Luclia plans to start a guinea pig farm. Lucia needs a loan of 750 soles that she will use to buy equipment for sheds. Lucila dreams about her children becoming professionals and about improving her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy equipment for sheds

loans.name: Masuda

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Маъсуда торгует на Школьной ярмарке канцелярскими товарами. У нее большой  ассортимент товаров, поэтому есть постоянные клиенты из разных организаций. В бизнесе ей на каникулах помогают сын и дочь. Наступает школьный сезон,поэтому она хочет закупить учебные принадлежности. Она благодарно КИВЕ за  поддержку в ее бизнесе.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Masuda sells stationary supplies at the School fair. She has a wide variety of items and this is why she has regular customers from different organizations. Her son and daughter help her with the business during the recess. The school year is approaching and this is why she wants to buy school supplies. She is thanking Kiva for the support of her business.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school stationary supplies

loans.name: Loluama

texts.en:
Loluama T. (0) is a 28-year-old woman living in the town of Vaovai. She is married and has four school-aged children.

Loluama owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting taro for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 350 WST a month.

In 2009, Loluama joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 1,000 WST which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. The loan will be her first from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Raul

texts.es: Raúl es un joven de 28 años, vive solo en una casa alquilada, ya que es huérfano de padre y madre, pero tiene una hermana que ocasionalmente lo visita. Años atrás se dedicaba a diversos trabajos como operario en la ciudad de Santa Ana, en ese tiempo logró ahorrar lo suficiente para comprar una parcela. Cumplido ese objetivo, ahora se ha propuesto sembrar plátanos, porque considera que es un fruto muy rentable, ya que se cosecha cada quince días y a veces semanalmente. Raúl acaba de mudarse a esta comunidad, llamada “Sanchirio”, donde recién está haciendo amistades. Y por el momento está haciendo limpieza de su nueva chacra, quitando los arbustos y malezas para después fumigar y en menos de 3 meses cree que ya recolectará sus primeros plátanos. Inicialmente piensa negociarlos a los compradores que van a esa zona, pero con el pasar de los años piensa incrementar sus chacras  con la finalidad de convertirse en mayorista. Asimismo lo acaban de nombrar presidente de su banco comunal, el cual se acaba de formar, por lo que es su primer crédito con MFP, por ello hace compromisos de no defraudar tal confianza. El dinero que viene solicitando lo piensa invertir en la compra de insecticidas y 6 sacos de fertilizantes químicos para sus plantaciones de plátano.
texts.en:
Raúl is 28 years old and lives alone in a rented house. His parents are deceased, but he has a sister who occasionally visits him. Years ago, he worked as a laborer at various jobs in the city of Santa Ana. He managed to save enough money to buy a plot of land. He decided to grow bananas, which has proven to be very profitable. He harvested bananas every two weeks, and sometimes weekly.

Raúl recently moved to the community called “Sanchirio” and is already making new friends. At the moment, he spends most of his time on his new property cleaning – removing bushes and weeds, and also spraying for pests. He expects his first harvest of bananas to be ready in less than 3 months. Initially, he thought it would be best to negotiate with buyers who pass through the area. He now plans to increase his output with the intention of becoming a direct wholesaler.

Raúl is a member of a Communal Bank that recently formed, and he has just been appointed to be the chairman for the group. This will be his first loan with MFP and he is committed not to betray his group’s trust. He will use the money he requested to buy insecticides and 6 sacks of chemical fertilizer for his banana crops.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers & insecticides

loans.name: Joane Soquissane

texts.pt:
Joane nasceu na província de inhambane, distrito de panda (onde opera a maior companhia de gás natural), tem 39 anos de idade e é pai de três filhos com idades compreendidas entre 4 e 10 anos que estudam na escola publica local. Estudou ate 7 classe e tendo interrompido forcosamente para cumprir o serviço militar Obrigatório.
Vive somente com a esposa e filhos na casa própria. Tem mandado algum valor para a mãe que vive na cidade de maputo.

Saiu de Panda (inhambane) em 1987 para a cidade de xai-xai, onde cumpriu o serviço militar obrigatório e quatro anos depois passou a disponibilidade. Foi afecto na empresa de caminhos de ferro de Moçambique, onde trabalha ate então como acertador da linha ferra. Para alem de trabalhar para a empresa, joane e a esposa dedicam se a venda de produtos de primeira necessidade (oleio, maionese, açúcar, farinha de milho, bebidas e outros) num estabelecimento comercial próprio. 

Aprendeu a fazer negocio com amigos ha. 19 anos e vende mais oleio alimentar obtendo um lucro mensal de 10.000,00MT. Adquire o produto localmente. Na sua empresa recebe 7.500,00MT, como salário mensal, que aplica no sustento da família e pagamento de credito. Nunca teve créditos com outros bancos.

Este é o quarto empréstimo de joane no valor de 12.000,00MT para compra e venda de produtos de primeira necessidade. Os anteriores créditos foram de 5.200,00MT, 8.000,00MT e 9.000,00MT todos para a mesma actividade e pagos sem problemas. Propõe se apagar o credito o mais urgente possível para poder aceder a mais empréstimos com objectivo de ampliar o seu estabelecimento comercial.
texts.en:
Joane was born in the province of Inhambane in the district of Panda (where the largest natural gas company operates). He is 39 and is the father of three children, whose ages range from 4 to 10 years old. They study in the local public scool. He studied until seventh grade but inevitably had to stop to fulfill his obligatory military service. He lives with his wife and children in their own home. He has sent some money to his mother, who lives in the city of Maputo. He left Panda (and Inhambane) in 1987 to go to the city of Xai-Xai, where he fulfilled his obligatory military service, and four years later, he was able to leave the service. He now works for a train company in Mozambique. In addition to working for this company, Joane and his wife sell basic goods (oil, mayonnaise, sugar, corn flour, beverages, etc.) in their own location. He learned to run his business from friends 19 years ago. He sells mostly cooking oil and earns monthly wages of 10,000 Mozambique meticais. He acquires his product locally. In his company, he received a monthly salary of 7,500 meticais, which he uses to feed his family and will use to make his payments. He has never had credits from another bank. This is Joane's fourth loan, and it is in the amount of 12,000 meticais. He will use it to buy basic goods to sell. His previous credits were for 5200, 8000, and 9000 meticais, which were all for the same activity and were paid back without any problems. He proposes to pay his credit back as soon as possible to be able to receive more loans with the objective of expanding his location.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell merchandise (cooking oil, beverages, etc.)

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Pilar G. is blessed with four children; luckily she is able to nurture them with the help of her general store that is contributing a lot to supporting their family. Her four children are not all studying. They are living in the simple community of Bolinao Aurora, Isabela. Her family lives in that place happy and contented. Pilar also is happy that her family has a good relationship.

She wants her business become progressive and because she lacks with enough business capital, Pilar wants to apply for a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 6,000 that will serve as additional business capital for her store. With already 18 years managing the business, Pilar is hoping that her business will somehow develop its sustainability for the future welfare of her children and whatever purposes may serve to the welfare of her children.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Mally

texts.en:
Mally P., 47 years old, is a rice farmer. She has seven children. Her eldest child is 25 and she has been doing her best to be able to buy her family food, clothes and other needs. She has been wishing that her farm has an abundant harvest. In that way, she will be able to better support her family.

She is for asking a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and buy the necessary tools to grow her harvest. She will also use the loan to pay the laborers who helped prapare the soil. The loan is very helpful to sustain her livelihood.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Dashuu

texts.en:
Dashhuu B. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a small house in the Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. Her oldest son and daughter attend a local secondary school and her youngest son is in kindergarten. Her husband is currently employed at a local auto-repair business as a mechanic. 

B. manages a clothes-trading business at the local market in her town. She started her business in 2003 as a partnership with a close friend. She was able to quickly learn much about the management and marketing for a clothing business as her friend and partner already had previous experience in the trade. B. has made much progress with her clothing business and has increased her business capital from 1,500,000 tugrugs ($1,050) when she started to a level exceeding 4,000,000 tugrugs ($2,800) today. Her earnings have enabled her to buy a new house for her and her family, which has much improved their quality of life. 

For the future, B. hopes to use her experience to operate her own clothing store. She wants to sell a wider variety of clothes to meet all of her customers' needs. She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug loan to import clothes from China to sell.

loans.use: To import clothes from China to sell

loans.name: Norng

texts.en: Norng S. is 64 years of age, a widow woman, and currently lives in a medium-size wooden house in Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia. She has two children and she was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. Norng S. and her children own a small handicraft business; they turn rattan into furniture for sale. Norng S. will be using her Kiva loan to purchase more rattan for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more rattan for her furniture making business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn S. is from the village of Hubangon, Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old. Jocelyn is married. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: O. T. Mohammed is a male Ugandan who is 50 years old and married with five children in school at the primary level. His wife is also a small-scale businesswoman. He has a retail shop which he has been operating for over four years. He is using the loan to purchase retail items such as OMO (a detergent product), soap, matchboxes, drinks and so forth, for the expansion of the business. His business dream is to upgrade his retail shop.

loans.use: To purchase items such as OMO, soap, match boxes, drinks, etc., to sell

loans.name: Edwin Rene

texts.es:
El Señor C. esta casado con 2 hijos de edades de 5 y 2 años,  su esposa trabaja como comerciante,  el inicio su negocio de elaboración de muebles hace 10 años.
El esta solicitando su crédito para comprar tela, madera y esponja para construir más muebles,  en su tienda en donde vende muebles tiene 1 empleados y en la fábrica tiene 5 empleados.
El ha tenido 3 créditos grupales con FAPE y ha sido muy cumplido con sus compromisos y este es su primer préstamo con Kiva.
Su sueño es ampliar su local para venta de muebles.
texts.en:
Edwin Rene is married with a 5-year old and a 2-year old. His wife works in retail. He started his furniture making business 10 years ago.

He is requesting a loan to buy fabric, wood and foam to build more furniture. His furniture store has one employee and the factory has 5 employees.

He has requested 3 group loans with FAPE and has always complied with his commitments. This is his first Kiva loan.

His dream is to expand his furniture store.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, wood and foam to build furniture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda B. is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 41 years old. Esmeralda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Esmeralda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Esmeralda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Esmeralda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esmeralda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28000 PHP from ASKI. Esmeralda is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Esmeralda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Jeronica Enoque

texts.pt:
Jeronica Enoque S. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Provincia de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 44 anos de idade, devorciada mae de 2 filhos de 15 e 24 anos de idade a mais nova continua a estudar. Fez somente 5 classe não continuou devido a falta de condiçoes financeiras por parte dos progenitores. Vive na casa propria com os seus filhos e nao sustenta mais ninguem.
 Nunca saiu da Província de Maputo, quando casou se esteve a viver na cidade de Maputo. 12 anos depois separou se e veio residir em Boane. Tem um negócio próprio há mais de 15 anos, não possui nenhum empregado, nao tem horario fixo, e trabalha através de encomendas. Vende televisores e DVDs e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 10.000.00mt por mes, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum atravez de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa ).
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da senhora Argentina amiga vendedora do mercado de Boane que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 5º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos para revender (Televisores, DVDs e outros) aumentando a quantidade e diversificar ainda mais a sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 7.200.00mt, 10.500.00mt, 14.000.00mt e20.000.00mt todos para  a mesma actividade.
No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para terminar a sua residencia e melhorar ainda o seu estabelecimento comercial.
texts.en:
Jeronica Enoque S. was born in the city of Matola, Maputo Province, in southern Mozambique. She is 44 years old, and is a divorced mother of 2 children who are 15 and 24 years old. The youngest continues to go to school. She only completed the 5th grade and did not continue due to her parents' lack of financial means. She lives in her own house with her children and does not support anyone else. She has never left Maputo Province. When she married, she went to live in the city of Maputo. She she and her husband separated 12 years later, she went to live in Boane. She has had her own business for more than 15 years. She does not have any help at her job, does not have a fixed schedule, and works by filling orders. She sells televisions and DVD players and earns about 10,000 MZN per month, which she uses to pay for household costs. She even saves some through Xitique (a traditional rotating savings system). She has never had loans through other banks. She found out about Hluvuku through Mrs. Argentina, a friend of hers who sells good at the Boane market and who is also a client of the institution. This is her fifth loan, which has a value of 25,000 MZN. She plans to use it to goods to resell (televisions, DVD players, etc.) in order to increase her supply and diversify her merchandise. Her previous loans were for 7,200 MZN, 10,500 MZN, 14,000 MZN, and 20,000 MZN, all for the same purpose. In the future she would like to ask for more loans in order to finish building her house and also to further improve her commercial business.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell domestic electronics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional charcoal in bulk .

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo T. is from the village of Binunsaran, Mambajao Camiguin Province. He is 25 years old and married with two small children. To make a living, he runs a transportation service with his "motorela" or pedicab. He has been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Alfredo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI and is now requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to improve his service to passengers. It will be the fourth loan he has taken out from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to improve his business

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia A. is a single parent living with her three children. She has no formal education.

Afia sells maize at Jukwa and uses the income she gets from her sales to provide shelter, food and clothing for her children.

Afia will use the loan to purchase more maize to sell. With the new profits from her extended business, she plans to save to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more maize to sell

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Yacouba Traoré  a 33 ans, marié et père de six enfants. Il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Bougoula Hameau situé environ à 7km de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Yacouba Traoré, après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au commerce d’articles divers de boutique. Il dispose d’une boutique devant son domicile où il mène cette activité d’achat et vente des articles divers  tels le maïs,  les Cigarettes, les bonbons,  les allumettes,  les Cheewing Gum, du lait en poudre,  du Thé, du  sucre, des  savons, etc  il y a environ douze 12 ans. 
Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois  ans. 
Après  avoir correctement remboursés les deux prêts précédents, il est à son troisième prêt qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 tonnes de maïs, 12 cartouches de Cigarettes différentes, 2 carton du thé, 4 sacs du sucre, 12 paquets de lait en poudre, 5 paquets de bonbon, 10 paquet de Chewing Gum, 30 paquets d’allumette, 5 cartons de savons.
 Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes de la ville avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée de toute la couches sociale de sa localité.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yacouba Troré is 33 yars of age, married and the father of six children. He lives with his wife and children in an extend traditional family in the village of Bougoula, about 7 km (4 miles) from the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Mr. Yacouba Traoré, after trying different business activities without success, launched a general store. He keeps a small store in front of his house, where he sells diverse articles such as cornmeal, cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, soaps etc. He has been doing for about 12 years. His business is very popular with the customers due to the quality of his goods. In order to satisfy the ever growing demand, three years ago he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After having duly repaid his previous two loans, he is now on his third loan, which will be used to purchase 4 tons of cornmeal, 12 cartons of different kinds of cigarettes, 2 cartons of tea, 4 bags of sugar, 12 packs of powdered milk, 5 packs of candy, 10 packs of chewing gum, 30 packs of matches, and 5 cartons of soap. He purchases his stock from wholesale retailers in town and sells retail, for cash or on credit, to a customer base representing all social layers of his neighborhood. With this loan, he anticipates achieving a monthly income of 250,000 West African Francs, which will be used essentially to bolster his business capital, contribute to the family budget, pay off the interest on his loan and reinvest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various articles (for resale)

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes sells mouth watery Nigerian cooked foods. She has been in this business for long in her community. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to see her business and family life make progress. She has been in this business for long. She is 39 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is a tailor and he also supports their home. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Cristina

texts.es:
La Sra. Cristina G. esta casada hace 19 años y tiene 2 hijos de 18 y 19 años.
 Desde hace 20 años se dedica a la venta de artículos de primera necesidad en su propio local.
 Cristina acudió a la Fundación Paraguaya para que atraves de un crédito pudiera invertir en la compra de mercadería (azúcar, yerba, arroz, bebidas)  para surtir más su despensa.
Con este negocio ella consigue ayudar a su marido quien no posee un ingreso fijo ya que cobra por jornal por los trabajos que realiza como plomero, electricista y jardinero.
En un futuro la señora Cristina quiere seguir ampliando su clientela y así obtener una  mayor ganancia de su negocio
texts.en:
Sra. Cristina G. has been married for 19 years and has 2 children, 18- and 19-years old. She has operated a business, in her own shop, selling everyday grocery products. Cristina approached Fundacion Paraguaya to get a loan so that she can buy merchandise (sugar, yerba, rice, drinks) for her store. Cristina's husband helps her with the business. He doesn't have a fixed income and has to depend on day work doing plumbing, electrical work and gardening. For the future, Cristina wants to go on expanding her customer base so that she can increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to resell.

loans.name: Valeria

texts.es:
Valeria es pequeña productora que habita en el municipio de Nueva Guinea en la comarca Villa Alvarez junto a su esposo y su hijo,  quienes trabajan como familia en las actividades del campo. Valeria  desde muy pequeña ha trabajado en esta actividad ya que sus padres le enseñaron como cuidar del ganado y la agricultura, y con esta experiencia ha podido tener su propio inventario ganadero. 

Esta solicitando su 5to crédito a la institución de AFODENIC para compra de ternero desarrollo, para engordarlos y posteriormente comercializarlos  a un precio justo en el que pueda recibir mayor ganancia, y de esta manera fortalecer su inventario ganadero, y mejorar la calidad de vida del núcleo familiar.  

El mayor anhelo de Valeria es de aumentar su inventario ganadero, así salir adelante con otros ingresos, para tener un vida justa y humana.
texts.en:
Valeria is a small cattle rancher who lives in the Nueva Guinea municipality in the rural community of Villa Alvarez. She lives with her husband and son. They work the land together as a family. Valeria has worked in this activity since she was a little girl. Her parents taught her how to take care of the cattle and to farm. With this experience she has been able to have her own herd of livestock. She is requesting her fifth loan with the AFODENIC institution. She will buy a calf to raise and fatten. Later she will sell it for a fair price so that she can get greater income. This is the way to strengthen her herd of cattle and improve the quality of life for her family. Valeria’s greatest desire is to increase her herd. That way she will get ahead with other income in order to have a just and humane life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a calf

loans.name: Tossa

texts.en: Monsieur Tossa G. is 35 years old and works in Lomé, Togo where he has a restaurant. He takes care of his one child; his wife is now dead. To feed his family, Mr. G. has a restaurant called Café-Bar-Resto-Shalom. He’s had the restaurant since 2007. He has requested a loan from WAGES of 300,000 CFA to help him grow the restaurant by increasing the menu and capacity.

loans.use: To expand his restaurant

loans.name: Benkadi  1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi  I  fait partie de l’association des femmes mariées du village de SESSO dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 36  ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent essentiellement de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
HAWA S. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, exclusivement  au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, la récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de TENE,  de MOPTI  et dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
HAWA S. compte réaliser, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 40.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi I group is part of the married women’s association of the Sesso village in the San prefecture, in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women live in traditional families. They are on the average 36 years old and have five children. Their main business is growing peanuts. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, and are now on their first agricultural loan. Hawa S. plans to use her loan to purchase a sufficient supply of peanut seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs, specifically at the big market in Tene. After the winter season, the harvest is stored for a while as its price increases, before being sold at the big market of Tene, the market of Mopti and other nearby markets, retail (often wholesale) for cash to customers mostly coming from big towns. After selling her products, Hawa S. plans to earn an income, of 40,000 West African francs, which will be used to pay off the loan interest and cover ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Angelina Selina Adhiambo

texts.en:
Angeline Selina Adhiambo O. is 45 years old. She is married and has four children. She started a water vending business in 2007 to meet her daily needs and that of her entire family after she quit selling shoes due to low income. 

With only one supply outlet, Angelina wants to have more--especially in areas with no water outlets at all--something that will see her earn considerable income. She wishes to get a loan worth 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to expand her network of outlets as she works towards socio-economic stability for herself and her family.

loans.use: Create more water distribution outlets

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
la sra. Beatriz E. tiene 42 años de edad, vive en el barrio Suyapa de la ciudad de Nacaome, radica
en ese lugar desde hace 19 años, ahi se han crecido todos sus hijos, dedicandose por varios años a la elaboracion y venta de tortillas, este negocio lo realiza junto con su hija menor, vende las tortillas en el mercado de Nacaome y con varios clientes fijos que tiene que recogen las tortillas en su casa.
 
la señora E. es una madre viuda que ha educado a sus hijos luchando ya que su esposo murio hace varios años y le ha tocado mantener a la familia y sacarla adelante
 
el credito lo utilizara parar comprar harina de maiz, leña, cal, agua y fosforos.
gracias a su negocio a mejorado la condiciones de vida de su familia, ya que con las ganancias hizo un baño,
puso piso de la casa, mejoro la cocina y otras cosas.
texts.en:
Sra. Beatriz E., 42, lives in the Suyapa neighborhood of the Honduran city of Nacaome. She settled in the town 19 years ago and raised her children there. She has earned a living, for several years, making and selling tortillas, a business that she operates with her youngest daughter. She sells the tortillas to customers in the market at Nacaome and to a few regular customers who pick up tortillas at her house. Sra. E. is a widow who has struggled since her husband's death to make sure that her children are educated and that the family get ahead in the world. Sra. E. will use the loan to buy flour, wood, quicklime, water and matches. Thanks to the business, she has managed to improve the lives of her family by building a bathroom, laying a floor, improving the kitchen and other things, as well.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for food business.

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
La Señora María Elena vive en las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad se levanta sobre la antigua ciudad inca de Tomebamba,  tiene un clima frió, amenos paisajes del entorno, la abundancia de agua y la fama de sus habitantes por su habilidad de orfebres y ceramistas hacen de esta ciudad una de las más bellas del Ecuador.

Doña María se encuentra en su segundo crédito que realiza en la banca comunal y fue una compañera la que la incentivo a formar parte de este grupo de mujeres que buscan un mejor porvenir, trabaja como secretaria de un radio taxi en el cual lleva 8 años, su horario de trabajo es de domingo a domingo en horarios rotativos, también vende productos YANBAL, en este negocio lleva 3 años, los vende en su tiempo libre y nos comenta que los créditos le han beneficiado mucho en su negocio.

La Señora. María tiene 29 año, es casada y tiene un hijo  de 8 años de edad, su esposo es empleado privado, no poseen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando. El nuevo crédito que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le hace entrega lo va a invertir en la compra de productos YANBAL. Su sueño  es  estudiar medicina.
texts.en:
María Elena lives in the outskirts of the city of Cuenca which is built above the ancient Inca city of Tomebamba. Its climate is cold, it has pleasant surroundings, an abundance of water and its residents are famous for their silver and ceramic crafts thus making this city one of Ecuador’s most beautiful. María is in her 2nd loan with the communal bank. She was encouraged by a coworker to become part of this group of women who seek a better future. She’s been employed as a secretary at a radio-dispatch taxi firm for 8 years. She works rotating shifts from Sunday to Sunday. She has also sold YANBAL products for 3 years in her free time and she mentioned to us that the loans have been very beneficial to her business. María is 29 years old, married and has an 8-year-old son. Her husband is a private employee. They do not own their home, they are renters. The new loan that FUNDACION ESPOIR will grant will be used to buy YANBAL products. Her dream is to study medicine.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Yanbal brand cosmetics and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Katana

texts.en:
Katana is a married man with seven children (three boys and four girls) who all attend school. He has been operating a food stall for the last year. He sells food from a shop and from home to neighbors, students and passers-by. His wife helps in the running of the food stall.
Previously, Katana was employed as a shop assistant. With his loan of 20,000 KES, he wants to add stock by purchasing a sack of beans, rice, cooking oil and charcoal for cooking. Katana faces the major challenges of competition and seasonality in his business. During June his business does very well because of schoolchildren but business decreases during August because most students are on holiday.
Katana hopes to open a business selling firewood in the future in order to make more profit to enable him to provide for his family's needs. He joined Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to improve his living standards and also his business. Katana rents a house with no electricity or piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing, school fees and rent bills.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of beans, rice, cooking oil and charcoal for cooking

loans.name: Milagrina's Group

texts.en:
Milagrina S. is from the village of Mangandingay Cabarroguis, Quirino. She is 59 years old. Milagrina is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Milagrina S..

Milagrina is widowed and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Milagrina owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Milagrina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Milagrina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Milagrina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Milagrina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Milagrina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Jaqueline

texts.es: Jaqueline, de 29 años, es una mujer luchadora y buena, es madre soltera y adora a su hija Yusbeth de 9 años, juntas viven en su casa propia ubicada en la localidad de Chiras. Hace ya 10 años que viene dedicándose a la agricultura; donde siembra papa y arveja, los que posteriormente vende en el mercado central de su ciudad. Como mujer emprendedora y capaz, ha decidido expandirse más, pues su hija esta creciendo y necesita mayores cuidados y dedicaciones, fue entonces que con el poco dinero ahorrado compró un pequeño puesto en el mercado de su localidad, ahí vende papa y hortalizas a los pobladores que todos los días compra para el almuerzo de casa. En adelante ella está pensando comprar más terrenos de cultivo en los cuales podrá sembrar mayor cantidad de papa, de esa manera podrá comercializar en la capital de su país. Es el primer crédito con MFP y está muy contenta de pertenecer a un grupo comunal, donde está segura podrá salir adelante. Con el crédito que solicita, podrá comprar más cantidad de semillas de papa.
texts.en: Jaqueline is 29 years old and is a very good, hard-working woman.  She is a single mother who adores her 9 year old daughter Yusbeth.  They live together in their own home located in the city of Chiras.  Ten years ago, she started working in agriculture growing potatoes and peas which she sells in the city's central market.  As a capable, enterprising woman, she has decided to expand her business now that her daughter is growing and needs more of her time.  She took the small amount of money she saved and bought a small stand in the local market.  She sells potatoes and vegetables to the locals who come to buy food for their lunches everyday.  In the future, she would like to buy more land to grow more potatoes which she could sell in the country's capital.  This is her first loan through MFP and she is very grateful to belong to the village bank which she is sure will help her move forward.  She will use the loan to buy more potato seeds.

loans.use: Comprar semillas de papa.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his small shop by buying more items to sell to his customers

loans.name: Sirochidin

texts.ru: Каландаров Сирочидин житель города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 54 года. Женат. Отец четверых детей. Образование среднее – специальное, агроном. По профессии работает более 30 лет. Кроме того занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи и сеет пшеницу. В этой области уже 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян. Он намерен расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Sirochidin K. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  He is 54 years old, married and a father of four children.  He has a secondary-specialized education, as an agronomist.  Sirochidin has been working in his field for over 30 years.  Besides this, he is involved in agriculture.  He has a land plot at his house, where he grows vegetables and plants wheat.  He has been in this field for 10 years.  Sirochidin is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.  He intends to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn B. is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 37 years old. Jenelyn is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Jenelyn owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, instant noodles, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Jenelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jenelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Jenelyn is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & to use as working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jenelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cloth and thread

loans.name: Ubania

texts.es:
Ubania del Carmen P. es una mujer trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora de 33 años la cual es dueña de una barbería la cual inicio con una silla de barbería que compro de segunda mano en la actualidad con este crédito piensa comprar una silla nueva especial para la barbería. 
Ella era integrante del grupo Brizas del Mar la cual fue graduada a crédito individual ya que el crecimiento de su negocio y su buena historia de crédito cumple para la metodología individual.
texts.en: Ubania del Carmen P. is a hardworking, enterprising, and tenacious woman. She's 33-years-old and she owns a barber's shop. She started this business with a second-hand barber's chair. Currently, with this loan, she hopes to buy a new chair. She was a member of the group Brizas del Mar, but she graduated to individual loans because her business grew and her good credit record made her eligible for an individual loan.

loans.use: Purchase of a special barber's chair

loans.name: Dative

texts.en:
Dative is a 29-year-old married woman with three children. One of her children attends school. Dative sells meat, which she has done for seven years. Her husband works in a cinema show. 

Dative will use the loan to purchase more meat. With the new profits from her expanded business, Dative plans to reinvest in her business and to help her family. In addition, she dreams of having more than one butchery in the future.

loans.use: To buy more meat to sell in her butcher shop

loans.name: Mary Kondua Ajoa

texts.en:
Mary Kondua Ajoa M. prepares porridge at Elmina. She serves it with sugar, milk, and bread. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a cashier. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. 

Her loan will be used to acquire extra bags of maize to be able to produce in a larger quantity for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy a plot of land. 

The mortar and pestle in the photo are what she uses to pound the maize before sending it to the mill.

loans.use: acquire extra bags of maize

loans.name: Rosa Matilde

texts.es: Mercedes Matilde tiene 44 años, su actividad es la venta de ropa usada. Esta no es la primera vez que solicita financiamiento pues han sido beneficiosos para ella. Hace más de 8 años que tiene este negocio, Mercedes tiene 1 hija de menor de edad a su cargo, siempre está buscando la forma de mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia. Este crédito es para la compra de pantalones, faldas, camisas, entre otros productos que le solicitan.
texts.en: Mercedes Matilde, 44, sells used clothing.  This isn’t her first loan request since they have been very beneficial for her.  She’s had the business for over 8 years.  Mercedes has a minor daughter in her care.  She is always seeking ways to improve her family’s living conditions.  This loan will be to buy pants, skirts and shirts among other products requested.

loans.use: To buy pants, skirts, shirts, etc.

loans.name: Duo Getzemani De Sacatepequez Group

texts.es:
Duo Getzemani de Sacatepequez: es integrante por doña Felipa T., Soltera pero hace 14 años su vida cambio cuando le regalaron una nena convirtiendola en madre soltera, teniendo asi la compania y ayuda de su niña, quien tambien la ayuda a la venta de ropa tipica de su comunidad de donde ella es originaria ella tambien se dedica a la venta de tejidos y servilletas.
Doña Agustina Quien teje servilletas tipicas desde muy pequeña manifiesta que son muy vendibles en la localidad y fuera, dice tener la ayuda de sus 4 hijas que al regresar de la escuela la ayudan en este oficio con la que ella colabora al sosten y educacion de sus hijos.
Las dos expresan lo dificil que es la vida economicamente para ellas y su familia pero sus hijos son las que les motivan diariamente, quieren brindarle educacion a sus hijos para que ellos en un futuro no pasen lo que ellas han vivido, pero a Dios gracias tienen salud y ganas de luchar diariamente, las dos solicitan el credito para la compra de hilo para comfeccion de tejidos.
texts.en:
Getzemani de Sacatepequez Duo: 

Mrs. Felipa T. is single but 14 years ago her life changed when she was given a baby girl turning her into a single mother.  She now has the companionship and help of her daughter who also helps her sell clothing typical of the community she’s from.  She also sells weavings and napkins.

Agustina has woven typical napkins since she was very little.  She states that they are quite salable in her location and in other locations.  She has four daughters that help her when then come home from school.  This works allows her to help with her children’s support and education.

Both of them state how difficult life is for them and their families economically.  However, their children motivate them daily.  They want to provide their children with education so that they will have better futures and not go through what they’ve had to endure.  Thanks to God, though, they have their health and the drive to work every day.

Both are asking for funds to buy thread to make their weavings.

loans.use: To buy thread to make weavings.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Mariées toutes dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 36 ans et 5 enfants, les six membres du groupe Benkadi habitent à Pelengana, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché de Pelengana. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de condiments (choux pommés, échalotes et pâtes alimentaires), préparation et vente de jus locaux, calebasses et charbon de bois. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont adhéré au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 8ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Mah Traoré a une grande réputation à Pelengana pour sa vente de calebasses de tous calibres. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée par les jeunes mariées pour constituer leur trousseau de mariage. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 4 colis de calebasses en gros à la foire de Tonna. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché de Pelengana, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Mah Traoré espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge certains besoins du foyer. 
Elle a pour objectif de devenir grossiste dans cette activité à travers ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The six members of the Benkadi group, all married women living in monogamous families, are on the overage 36 years old, with five children.  The group members live in Plenegana, the central locality of a rural community in the Ségou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali).

They know each other through working as vendors at the Pelengana markets. The group members retail condiments (cabbage, potatoes, shallots and pasta),  self-made juice of local fruits, gourds and charcoal. In order to increase their working capital, the group members have decided to joint the Soro Yiriwaso credit program and are now on their 8th solidarity loan.

Mrs. Mah Traoré is well-known in Pelengana as a vendor of gourds of all sizes.  She is very much sought after by brides-to-be putting together their wedding trousseaux.She plans to use her loan to purchase four packages of gourds, wholesale, at the Tonna market. She resells her goods for cash and on credit, out of her home, as an ambulant vendor and at the Pelengana market, to a customer base composed of women and men.
With this loan, Mrs. Mah Traoré hopes to achieve an average monthly income of 22,000 West African Francs, which will be used to pay for some  household needs, with the rest reinvested in her business. Her goal is to become a wholesaler in this field, thanks to the collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To purchase gourds

loans.name: Dios Con Nosotros 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Altagracia, the coordinator of her group, Dios con Nosotros 1 & 2 (God with us), lives with her four children in the city of La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

Altagracia has been selling coconut and milk candies for over three years, having started her business with some savings. She will be receiving her first Esperanza loan with which she will purchase goods to make those candies. Altagracia's principal objective is to become a big businesswoman for the rest of her life and to have a large candy store with an outside area in her community.

loans.use: to buy sugar, coconut, etc.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea N., 62, is a farmer and her husband is a construction worker, and they can earn a daily income $1.66 per day. Chea N. has six children, five of whom are married while the remaining one is single. There of her children were employed as sewing workers and have a formal salary every month. 

She intends to buy a new motorcycle and repair her old house. This loan can make life easier for them as they can go anywhere faster than before. As for her future expectations, she hopes to sells all kinds of meals and vegetables in front of her house.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle and repair her old house.

loans.name: Vicentina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “QORILAZO”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Vicentina; ella tiene 25 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de papa, la socia vende papa en forma ambulatoria, ella trabaja desde las 9:00 a.m hasta las 5:00 p.m, por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de papa. La socia solicita el préstamo para pagar deudas personales como educación de sus hijos.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Vicentina is a member of the communal bank “QORILAZO”; the bank is located in the district of Cusco in the province and department of Cusco. 

Vicentina is 25-years-old. She lives with her partner and two children. She juggles her daily activities with her potato selling business. She sells potatoes in the streets and works from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. With this business she gets her children ahead. She wants to expand the potato selling business and she's requesting this loan to pay off personal debts, such as her children's education.

Vicentina is happy about the loan and she promises to make the payments.

loans.use: pay off personal debts, such as her her children's education.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle A. is from the city of Pantaon Ozamiz City. She is 25 years old. Michelle is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Michelle owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting gabi for sale. Michelle has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Michelle joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase seedlings and fertilizer for her farm. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has sevev branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy fruit: grapes and strawberries and also to buy vegetables: potatoes, chayote and carrots.

loans.name: Davit

texts.en:
Davit is a 28-year-old farmer from village Pkhvenisi. Davit and his mother live in their house in the village. Davit’s mother is 72 years old and retired. 

Davit has a milk cow whose milk is used for cheese production. Cheese is sold to the local retailer. Davit owns 4.7 ha of land. He grows approximately 12 tons of tomatoes and 14 tons of cabbage annually on this land. He has also planted 240 apple and 30 cherry trees. Vegetables and fruits are sold by Davit himself – he takes them with his own mini-bus to the nearby towns and sells there. With the requested credit Davit will till and cultivate 1.4 ha of land, where cabbage, tomatoes and maize will be grown. Part of the credit will be used for purchasing fertilizers. 

Davit hopes that after proper tilling of the land he will get a good harvest, which will be sold at a good price. With the received income Davit plans to renovate their house. In the near future, Davit is going to get married.

loans.use: to pay for tilling and cultivation of land and to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Leang is 49 years old and resides with her husband and children at Takeo province. She has sold food and traditional cake for children since 2005. Her income is US $5 per day. Her husband is a farmer and cow feeder at home, earning US $2 per day. She has four children. Three are students and the other one is working in a factory, earning US $2 per day. 

Each month, she has to spend US $40 on food, US $5 on utilities and US $20 on other expenses. 

Leang has asked for a loan of US $1,000 to purchase tile in order to tile the floor of her house. Her career right now can make good profit so she does not want to change to any other career. She will be working hard to keep her career running smoothly. 

For her children, she wants to send them to study at the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy tile to repair her house.

loans.name: Mouykea

texts.en:
Mouykea, 58 years old, is a roast chicken seller. She is a single mother with three children. One is studying and two are working. 

Without her husband, she has to support her children’s living and going to school. Even though she is alone, she has a strong commitment to take care all of her children and send them to school or to study a skill for their future. 

This family can make an income of about $9 per day. Every month, she has to spend around $45 on every expense in her family. 

She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy chickens to roast and sell.

loans.use: To buy chickens to roast and sell.

loans.name: Yaneth De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
La señora Yaneth de los Ángeles de 32 años de edad es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora madre de cinco niños de 15 años, 13 años, 10 años, 4 años y 6 meses de edad. Ella tiene una pulpería la cual inicio hace 15 años con la ayuda de su suegra y luego fue desarrollándolo hasta tener una venta surtida con los productos necesarios.
Ella invertirá el crédito en azúcar, arroz, frijoles, coca cola, pan, queso, aceite…etc. para seguir creciendo.
texts.en: Yaneth de los Ángeles, 32, is a hard working, enterprising mother of five children whose ages are 15, 13, 10, and 4 years and a 6-month-old.  She has a grocery store that she started fifteen years ago with help from her mother-in-law and then continued developing it until having a well stocked store with all the necessary products.  She will use the loan to buy sugar, rice, beans, Coca-Cola, bread, cheese, oil, etc. to continue growing.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Somaly

texts.en:
Somaly is a widow mother with one son and two daughters. She lives in a village along National Road Number Five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Somaly transferred her grocery store to her daughter because she has full-time employment. Previously, she requested a loan to buy a motorcycle and her daughter uses that motorbike for commuting and to carry grocery items from market to home. 

Hence Somaly decided to apply for another loan of $1,200 to buy one more motorbike to drive to work.  

Photo: Somaly is standing in her daughter’s grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to drive to work.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en: Editha is a 51-year-old widowed woman living in Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She cares for her two grown children. Supporting her family by herself is not an easy task. She has to spend double or triple the time working in order to earn enough money. For ten years, Editha has worked buying and selling recyclable items. She buys used recyclable items to sell to other buyers. This work earns her a monthly income of 6,464 PHP. Earlier this year, Editha applied for her first loan from GDMPC, a loan of 5,000 PHP. The money is intended to acquire more recyclable items such as empty bottles, cans, rusted iron, etc., to re-sell. Editha hopes to find a buyer that will offer a higher price. She also hopes to own a tricycle (three-wheeled) transport service in the future.

loans.use: To purchase recyclabe items for resale

loans.name: Mpara Abagamba Kamu Traders Group B.

texts.en:
Anna owns and runs a boutique in Mubende, which is in the central part of Uganda. She is a married mother of 3 children, who are between 14 and 20 years of age. All of her 3 children are in school.

Anna has run her business for about 12 years and, on average, she earns about 150,000 Ugandan shillings as profits per month. She is a very hard working lady who was encouraged by her friends and family members to start this business. Her customers are the local people in the area and she says her good association with people is the reason her business still stands.

With a Kiva loan, she intends to buy more clothes to resell.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Sabougnouma A Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe SABOUGNOUMA A sont des hommes tous  cultivateurs de maïs du village de Zoloko, dans la commune urbaine de Sikasso. Ils  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, ont moyenne  35 ans et   5 enfants. Le village Zoloko est situé à environ 19 km de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces hommes sont à leur premier cycle de prêt aux producteurs de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils produisent du maïs depuis plusieurs années et cette activité est d’une rentabilité sans pareille  pour eux.
Monsieur OUMAR,  debout au milieu, en chemise blanche est le président du groupe, avec son prêt il compte payer les frais de labours, acheter des intrants et de la semence pour entretenir : 1.5 hectares de maïs. 
La production est gardée pendant un certains temps, avant d’être vendue au niveau du village de Loutana et au marché de Sikasso, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de commerçants venant de grandes villes telles Sikasso, Bamako, etc. 
OUMAR espère réaliser un bénéfice de 185.000 FCFA  en fin de  campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi l’aider à entretenir sa famille.
texts.en:
The 10 men who make up the Sabougnouma A group are all corn farmers in the village of Zoloko, in the urban area of Sikasso.  They live in large traditional families, and they are an average of 35 years old with five children.  The village of Zoloko is about 19 km (12 mi)  from the city of Sikasso, in the 3rd administrative region of the republic of Mali.

These men are on their first loan cycle as corn farmers with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, in order to keep their farming business productive during the rainy season.  They have been producing corn for several years, and for them it is an unparalleled business in terms of profitability.

Oumar, who is standing in the middle in a white shirt, is the group’s president.  He plans on using his loan to pay costs of labor, and to purchase farm input and seeds to maintain 1.5 hectares (about 3.5 acres) of corn fields.  

The crop is stored for awhile before being sold in the village of Loutana and at the Sikasso market, to a clientele made up mostly of salespeople from large cities like Sikasso, Bamako, etc.

Oumar hopes to make a profit of 185,000 CFA francs at the end of the growing season.

This profit will enable him to pay off his loan and also to help cover his family’s expenses.

loans.use: to purchase farm input and seeds and to pay costs of labor

loans.name: Tsagaanbaatar

texts.en:
Tsagaanbaatar is a 55-year-old man who lives with his wife and daughter. His wife is a cook, but she has been helping her husband with his carpentry work since 2010. His daughter, who is 22 years old, graduated from university.

He started his business in 1990 by making small wood products. Now his business is doing well. He is confident that his business will be successful. His dream is to teach the next generation about wood products and techniques. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500,000 MNT to purchase more wood.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood

loans.name: Agustina Del Carmen

texts.es: Agustina labora como docente desde hace 25 años en la colonia San Juan, solicita el crédito para comprar un terreno para su hija menor, doña Agustina según referencias comerciales, laborales es una mujer de buenos principios, honesta y muy trabajadora, ella es una clienta fiel con la institución, ella recibe la ayuda economica de sus hijos mayores y por ingresos de su pequeña finca, su sueño en la vida es que su linda familia permanezca unida y que gozen de salud y estabilidad laboral.
texts.en: Agustina has been working as a teacher in the residential suburb of San Juan for 25 years.  She is requesting this loan to buy a plot of land for her youngest daughter.
